Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History: Reconstructing the lost field notes of Royal D. Suttkus using the notes of other collectors in the Royal D. Suttkus Fish Collection
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Tulane University to reconstruct the field notes of R.D. Suttkus and associate them with specimens in the fish collection. The collecting efforts of Suttkus and his collaborators amassed over 6 million specimens that is recognized as a National Center for Ichthyology Research. The field notes documenting critical environmental and locality characteristics for collected specimens were destroyed as a result of flooding by Hurricane Katrina. This project will facilitate the addition of rich sampling and environmental data, of the kind Suttkus and his associates recorded in their field notes, with the specimens housed in the Tulane University fish collection. This will enhance the value of the collection allowing researchers to use the data to address important scientific and societal needs such as research on fish species distribution, habitat conservation, environmental restoration, and species response to global change. The project will build on the researchers achievements in student training and broadening participation in collections-based endeavors.

The R.D. Suttkus Fish collection database at Tulane University, currently hosted on a Microsoft SQL Server, will be extended to support the additional fields and tables needed to capture the images and information contained within the field notes and logbooks. Field logbook and transcribed data sheet images will be captured using a NIKON Coolpix p90 v.1.0 camera mounted on a copy stand. Each image will be 4,000 pixels wide by 3,000 pixels wide with a bit depth of 24, horizontal resolution of 300 dots per inch and vertical resolution of 300 dots per inch. The RAW image file for each page photographed as well as an uncompressed TIFF will be preserved. A project technician and a number of student interns working in the summer will enter data from the field notes to the fish collection database and produce web content of Suttkus's professional career for an expanded Suttkus Memorial Website.

Institution.Name: Tulane University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: ADMINISTRATORS OF THE TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND, THE

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
When biologist Royal D. Suttkus joined the Tulane faculty in 1950, the university’s fish collection consisted of a just two dry-mounted specimens and 12 fluid-preserved lots of fishes held over from an early "University Museum". By the time Suttkus retired in 1990, the Tulane Museum of Natural History (TUMNH) fish collection had grown to over 6 million specimens and was recognized as a National Center for Ichthyology Research Resource Collection. The Tulane Fish Collection presently contains 7.6 million specimens and is recognized as the largest collection of post-larval fishes in the world. Remarkably, Suttkus himself made 10,107 field collections while affiliated with Tulane and had a hand in collecting 5,599,795 of the specimens in the fish collection.  No other figure in North American Ichthyology has come close to matching Suttkus’ total of collected specimens. In fact, Royal Suttkus’ contributions of specimens were so important that the collection was renamed the Royal D. Suttkus Fish Collection in October 2000.

Suttkus made his last field collection on 6 August 2005.  Less than a month later (29 August 2005), the Gulf Coast was ravaged by Hurricane Katrina.  Suttkus lost virtually all his possessions, including his personal field notes and most of his library.  What little remains is now part of the Suttkus Fish Collection. After the hurricane, Suttkus moved to the Atlanta metropolitan area.  He died surrounded by family in Decatur, Georgia on 28 December 2009.

The objective of this project was to recover as much information about Suttkus' field collecting as possible by digitizing the field notes of people who collected with him.  Document Technician, Jonathan Walczak, worked for three years, contacting associates of R.D. Suttkus, obtaining copies of their field notes, linking these notes to specific instances of Suttkus’ lost field notes, and imaging these notes and notes from logbooks salvaged from Suttkus’ home.  Of the 10,262 sheets of field notes that were in Suttkus' possession before the storm, Walczak managed to track down and digitize information from 6,876 pages of notes (67%), the majority of which were obtained from people who collected with Suttkus. 767 of the pages of field notes Walczak obtained were duplicates (copies of the same notes from multiple collectors). Thus, the number of unique field notes digitized in the project was 6,109. Since everything was digitized, we were able to compare the duplicates and reconcile data discrepancies.

Walczak also captured camera images and edited 5,667 pages of notes for permanent archive. Another 183 images were imaged by Suttkus associates who chose not to mail us their original notes to us. Walczak obtained notes from 23 different sources (collectors or members of their families), including 12 of the top 25 individuals who collected with Suttkus. Eleven potential sources of, seven of which were in the top 25, were determined to be deceased or no longer had pertinent records. Walczak attempted to contact additional sources but could not find current contact information.

In addition to digitizing notes received, Walczak recorded metadata from every set of notes he obtained. Data recorded included collector names; Royal D. Suttkus (RDS) numbers; collecting associate numbers; collection dates; sampling start and end times; locality information; basin/drainage data; methods of capture; associated image file names; alternative associated image file names for duplicates; and miscellaneous notes. Walczak also examined – and corrected when necessary – inconsistencies between different sets of records pertaining to the same collection events. He also flagged errors previously recorded in TUBRI’s main database so that the errors could be corrected.  Access to the digital field notes by researches is awaiting the pending migration of the Suttkus Fish Collection database to a new data management system.   

Walczak also led an effort to partner with Tulane's Louisiana Research Collection (LaRC) to conserve ,and preserve in perpetuity, the limited number of log books and pages of field notes that were rescued from Suttkus’ house after Hurricane Katrina. With data from these notes now independently digitized and recorded, the notes will be preserved as artifacts, and will be available to scholars and researchers in the future. The Tulane University Biodiversity Research Institute (TUBRI, formerly TUMNH) also partnered with the Biodiversity Heritage Library (BHL) to make images and data digitized during the project accessible as part of BHL's permanent online archive. As part of TUBRI’s outreach efforts, Walczak accompanied Collection Manager, Justin Mann, to five Louisiana STEM Expos, and shared details of Suttkus’ story with young, potential future scientists. In addition, Walczak added to the research PI Bart initiated in 2010 on Suttkus’ life story, including his personal and Tulane history. Documents pertaining to Suttkus were obtained via FOIA requests and archival research and added to TUBRI’s collection of records about Suttkus. The records will be published in a forthcoming book about Suttkus and his career.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2020
Modified by: Henry L Bart
